name: hadoop.common.configuration.version
description: version of this configuration file
label: environment

name: hadoop.tmp.dir
description: A base for other temporary directories.
label: environment

name: io.native.lib.available
description: Controls whether to use native libraries for bz2 and zlib compression codecs or not. The property does not control any other native libraries.
label: environment

name: hadoop.http.filter.initializers
description: A comma separated list of class names. Each class in the list must extend org.apache.hadoop.http.FilterInitializer. The corresponding Filter will be initialized. Then, the Filter will be applied to all user facing jsp and servlet web pages. The ordering of the list defines the ordering of the filters.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.security.authorization
description: Is service-level authorization enabled?
label: security

name: hadoop.security.instrumentation.requires.admin
description: Indicates if administrator ACLs are required to access instrumentation servlets (JMX, METRICS, CONF, STACKS).
label: security

name: hadoop.security.authentication
description: Possible values are simple (no authentication), and kerberos
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping
description: Class for user to group mapping (get groups for a given user) for ACL. The default implementation, org.apache.hadoop.security.JniBasedUnixGroupsMappingWithFallback, will determine if the Java Native Interface (JNI) is available. If JNI is available the implementation will use the API within hadoop to resolve a list of groups for a user. If JNI is not available then the shell implementation, ShellBasedUnixGroupsMapping, is used. This implementation shells out to the Linux/Unix environment with the bash -c groups command to resolve a list of groups for a user.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.dns.interface
description: The name of the Network Interface from which the service should determine its host name for Kerberos login. e.g. eth2. In a multi-homed environment, the setting can be used to affect the _HOST substitution in the service Kerberos principal. If this configuration value is not set, the service will use its default hostname as returned by InetAddress.getLocalHost().getCanonicalHostName(). Most clusters will not require this setting.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.dns.nameserver
description: The host name or IP address of the name server (DNS) which a service Node should use to determine its own host name for Kerberos Login. Requires hadoop.security.dns.interface. Most clusters will not require this setting.
label: environment

name: hadoop.security.dns.log-slow-lookups.enabled
description: Time name lookups (via SecurityUtil) and log them if they exceed the configured threshold.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.dns.log-slow-lookups.threshold.ms
description: If slow lookup logging is enabled, this threshold is used to decide if a lookup is considered slow enough to be logged.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.groups.cache.secs
description: This is the config controlling the validity of the entries in the cache containing the user->group mapping. When this duration has expired, then the implementation of the group mapping provider is invoked to get the groups of the user and then cached back.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.groups.negative-cache.secs
description: Expiration time for entries in the the negative user-to-group mapping caching, in seconds. This is useful when invalid users are retrying frequently. It is suggested to set a small value for this expiration, since a transient error in group lookup could temporarily lock out a legitimate user. Set this to zero or negative value to disable negative user-to-group caching.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.groups.cache.warn.after.ms
description: If looking up a single user to group takes longer than this amount of milliseconds, we will log a warning message.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.groups.cache.background.reload
description: Whether to reload expired user->group mappings using a background thread pool. If set to true, a pool of hadoop.security.groups.cache.background.reload.threads is created to update the cache in the background.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.groups.cache.background.reload.threads
description: Only relevant if hadoop.security.groups.cache.background.reload is true. Controls the number of concurrent background user->group cache entry refreshes. Pending refresh requests beyond this value are queued and processed when a thread is free.
label: performance

name: hadoop.security.groups.shell.command.timeout
description: Used by the ShellBasedUnixGroupsMapping class, this property controls how long to wait for the underlying shell command that is run to fetch groups. Expressed in seconds (e.g. 10s, 1m, etc.), if the running command takes longer than the value configured, the command is aborted and the groups resolver would return a result of no groups found. A value of 0s (default) would mean an infinite wait (i.e. wait until the command exits on its own).
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.connection.timeout.ms
description: This property is the connection timeout (in milliseconds) for LDAP operations. If the LDAP provider doesn't establish a connection within the specified period, it will abort the connect attempt. Non-positive value means no LDAP connection timeout is specified in which case it waits for the connection to establish until the underlying network times out.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.read.timeout.ms
description: This property is the read timeout (in milliseconds) for LDAP operations. If the LDAP provider doesn't get a LDAP response within the specified period, it will abort the read attempt. Non-positive value means no read timeout is specified in which case it waits for the response infinitely.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.url
description: The URL of the LDAP server to use for resolving user groups when using the LdapGroupsMapping user to group mapping.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl
description: Whether or not to use SSL when connecting to the LDAP server.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl.keystore
description: File path to the SSL keystore that contains the SSL certificate required by the LDAP server.
label: environment

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl.keystore.password.file
description: The path to a file containing the password of the LDAP SSL keystore. If the password is not configured in credential providers and the property hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl.keystore.password is not set, LDAPGroupsMapping reads password from the file. IMPORTANT: This file should be readable only by the Unix user running the daemons and should be a local file.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl.keystore.password
description: The password of the LDAP SSL keystore. this property name is used as an alias to get the password from credential providers. If the password can not be found and hadoop.security.credential.clear-text-fallback is true LDAPGroupsMapping uses the value of this property for password.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.credential.clear-text-fallback
description: true or false to indicate whether or not to fall back to storing credential password as clear text. The default value is true. This property only works when the password can't not be found from credential providers.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.credential.provider.path
description: A comma-separated list of URLs that indicates the type and location of a list of providers that should be consulted.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.credstore.java-keystore-provider.password-file
description: The path to a file containing the custom password for all keystores that may be configured in the provider path.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl.truststore
description: File path to the SSL truststore that contains the root certificate used to sign the LDAP server's certificate. Specify this if the LDAP server's certificate is not signed by a well known certificate authority.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.ssl.truststore.password.file
description: The path to a file containing the password of the LDAP SSL truststore. IMPORTANT: This file should be readable only by the Unix user running the daemons.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.bind.user
description: The distinguished name of the user to bind as when connecting to the LDAP server. This may be left blank if the LDAP server supports anonymous binds.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.bind.password.file
description: The path to a file containing the password of the bind user. If the password is not configured in credential providers and the property hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.bind.password is not set, LDAPGroupsMapping reads password from the file. IMPORTANT: This file should be readable only by the Unix user running the daemons and should be a local file.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.bind.password
description: The password of the bind user. this property name is used as an alias to get the password from credential providers. If the password can not be found and hadoop.security.credential.clear-text-fallback is true LDAPGroupsMapping uses the value of this property for password.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.base
description: The search base for the LDAP connection. This is a distinguished name, and will typically be the root of the LDAP directory.
label: environment

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.userbase
description: The search base for the LDAP connection for user search query. This is a distinguished name, and its the root of the LDAP directory for users. If not set, hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.base is used.
label: environment

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.groupbase
description: The search base for the LDAP connection for group search . This is a distinguished name, and its the root of the LDAP directory for groups. If not set, hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.base is used.
label: environment

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.filter.user
description: An additional filter to use when searching for LDAP users. The default will usually be appropriate for Active Directory installations. If connecting to an LDAP server with a non-AD schema, this should be replaced with (&(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)(uid={0}). {0} is a special string used to denote where the username fits into the filter. If the LDAP server supports posixGroups, Hadoop can enable the feature by setting the value of this property to "posixAccount" and the value of the hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.filter.group property to "posixGroup".
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.filter.group
description: An additional filter to use when searching for LDAP groups. This should be changed when resolving groups against a non-Active Directory installation. See the description of hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.filter.user to enable posixGroups support.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.attr.memberof
description: The attribute of the user object that identifies its group objects. By default, Hadoop makes two LDAP queries per user if this value is empty. If set, Hadoop will attempt to resolve group names from this attribute, instead of making the second LDAP query to get group objects. The value should be 'memberOf' for an MS AD installation.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.attr.member
description: The attribute of the group object that identifies the users that are members of the group. The default will usually be appropriate for any LDAP installation.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.attr.group.name
description: The attribute of the group object that identifies the group name. The default will usually be appropriate for all LDAP systems.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.search.group.hierarchy.levels
description: The number of levels to go up the group hierarchy when determining which groups a user is part of. 0 Will represent checking just the group that the user belongs to. Each additional level will raise the time it takes to execute a query by at most hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.directory.search.timeout. The default will usually be appropriate for all LDAP systems.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.posix.attr.uid.name
description: The attribute of posixAccount to use when groups for membership. Mostly useful for schemas wherein groups have memberUids that use an attribute other than uidNumber.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.posix.attr.gid.name
description: The attribute of posixAccount indicating the group id.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.ldap.directory.search.timeout
description: The attribute applied to the LDAP SearchControl properties to set a maximum time limit when searching and awaiting a result. Set to 0 if infinite wait period is desired. Default is 10 seconds. Units in milliseconds.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.providers
description: Comma separated of names of other providers to provide user to group mapping. Used by CompositeGroupsMapping.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.group.mapping.providers.combined
description: true or false to indicate whether groups from the providers are combined or not. The default value is true. If true, then all the providers will be tried to get groups and all the groups are combined to return as the final results. Otherwise, providers are tried one by one in the configured list order, and if any groups are retrieved from any provider, then the groups will be returned without trying the left ones.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.service.user.name.key
description: For those cases where the same RPC protocol is implemented by multiple servers, this configuration is required for specifying the principal name to use for the service when the client wishes to make an RPC call.
label: security

name: fs.azure.user.agent.prefix
description: WASB passes User-Agent header to the Azure back-end. The default value contains WASB version, Java Runtime version, Azure Client library version, and the value of the configuration option fs.azure.user.agent.prefix.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.security.uid.cache.secs
description: This is the config controlling the validity of the entries in the cache containing the userId to userName and groupId to groupName used by NativeIO getFstat().
label: security

name: hadoop.service.shutdown.timeout
description: Timeout to wait for each shutdown operation to complete. If a hook takes longer than this time to complete, it will be interrupted, so the service will shutdown. This allows the service shutdown to recover from a blocked operation. Some shutdown hooks may need more time than this, for example when a large amount of data needs to be uploaded to an object store. In this situation: increase the timeout. The minimum duration of the timeout is 1 second, "1s".
label: reliability

name: hadoop.rpc.protection
description: A comma-separated list of protection values for secured sasl connections. Possible values are authentication, integrity and privacy. authentication means authentication only and no integrity or privacy; integrity implies authentication and integrity are enabled; and privacy implies all of authentication, integrity and privacy are enabled. hadoop.security.saslproperties.resolver.class can be used to override the hadoop.rpc.protection for a connection at the server side.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.saslproperties.resolver.class
description: SaslPropertiesResolver used to resolve the QOP used for a connection. If not specified, the full set of values specified in hadoop.rpc.protection is used while determining the QOP used for the connection. If a class is specified, then the QOP values returned by the class will be used while determining the QOP used for the connection.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.sensitive-config-keys
value: secret$ password$ ssl.keystore.pass$ fs.s3.*[Ss]ecret.?[Kk]ey fs.s3a.*.server-side-encryption.key fs.azure.account.key.* credential$ oauth.*token$ hadoop.security.sensitive-config-keys
description: A comma-separated or multi-line list of regular expressions to match configuration keys that should be redacted where appropriate, for example, when logging modified properties during a reconfiguration, private credentials should not be logged.
label: security

name: hadoop.workaround.non.threadsafe.getpwuid
description: Some operating systems or authentication modules are known to have broken implementations of getpwuid_r and getpwgid_r, such that these calls are not thread-safe. Symptoms of this problem include JVM crashes with a stack trace inside these functions. If your system exhibits this issue, enable this configuration parameter to include a lock around the calls as a workaround. An incomplete list of some systems known to have this issue is available at https://wiki.apache.org/hadoop/KnownBrokenPwuidImplementations
label: reliability

name: hadoop.kerberos.kinit.command
description: Used to periodically renew Kerberos credentials when provided to Hadoop. The default setting assumes that kinit is in the PATH of users running the Hadoop client. Change this to the absolute path to kinit if this is not the case.
label: security

name: hadoop.kerberos.min.seconds.before.relogin
description: The minimum time between relogin attempts for Kerberos, in seconds.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.auth_to_local
description: Maps kerberos principals to local user names
label: security

name: hadoop.token.files
description: List of token cache files that have delegation tokens for hadoop service
label: security

name: io.file.buffer.size
description: The size of buffer for use in sequence files. The size of this buffer should probably be a multiple of hardware page size (4096 on Intel x86), and it determines how much data is buffered during read and write operations.
label: performance

name: io.bytes.per.checksum
description: The number of bytes per checksum. Must not be larger than io.file.buffer.size.
label: performance

name: io.skip.checksum.errors
description: If true, when a checksum error is encountered while reading a sequence file, entries are skipped, instead of throwing an exception.
label: reliability

name: io.compression.codecs
description: A comma-separated list of the compression codec classes that can be used for compression/decompression. In addition to any classes specified with this property (which take precedence), codec classes on the classpath are discovered using a Java ServiceLoader.
label: performance

name: io.compression.codec.bzip2.library
description: The native-code library to be used for compression and decompression by the bzip2 codec. This library could be specified either by by name or the full pathname. In the former case, the library is located by the dynamic linker, usually searching the directories specified in the environment variable LD_LIBRARY_PATH. The value of "system-native" indicates that the default system library should be used. To indicate that the algorithm should operate entirely in Java, specify "java-builtin".
label: environment

name: io.serializations
description: A list of serialization classes that can be used for obtaining serializers and deserializers.
label: performance

name: io.seqfile.local.dir
description: The local directory where sequence file stores intermediate data files during merge. May be a comma-separated list of directories on different devices in order to spread disk i/o. Directories that do not exist are ignored.
label: environment

name: io.map.index.skip
description: Number of index entries to skip between each entry. Zero by default. Setting this to values larger than zero can facilitate opening large MapFiles using less memory.
label: performance

name: io.map.index.interval
description: MapFile consist of two files - data file (tuples) and index file (keys). For every io.map.index.interval records written in the data file, an entry (record-key, data-file-position) is written in the index file. This is to allow for doing binary search later within the index file to look up records by their keys and get their closest positions in the data file.
label: performance

name: fs.defaultFS
description: The name of the default file system. A URI whose scheme and authority determine the FileSystem implementation. The uri's scheme determines the config property (fs.SCHEME.impl) naming the FileSystem implementation class. The uri's authority is used to determine the host, port, etc. for a filesystem.
label: environment

name: fs.default.name
description: Deprecated. Use (fs.defaultFS) property instead
label: environment

name: fs.trash.interval
description: Number of minutes after which the checkpoint gets deleted. If zero, the trash feature is disabled. This option may be configured both on the server and the client. If trash is disabled server side then the client side configuration is checked. If trash is enabled on the server side then the value configured on the server is used and the client configuration value is ignored.
label: performance

name: fs.trash.checkpoint.interval
description: Number of minutes between trash checkpoints. Should be smaller or equal to fs.trash.interval. If zero, the value is set to the value of fs.trash.interval. Every time the checkpointer runs it creates a new checkpoint out of current and removes checkpoints created more than fs.trash.interval minutes ago.
label: reliability

name: fs.protected.directories
description: A comma-separated list of directories which cannot be deleted even by the superuser unless they are empty. This setting can be used to guard important system directories against accidental deletion due to administrator error.
label: security

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.file.impl
description: The AbstractFileSystem for file: uris.
label: manageability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.har.impl
description: The AbstractFileSystem for har: uris.
label: manageability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.hdfs.impl
description: The FileSystem for hdfs: uris.
label: manageability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.viewfs.impl
description: The AbstractFileSystem for view file system for viewfs: uris (ie client side mount table:).
label: manageability

name: fs.viewfs.rename.strategy
description: Allowed rename strategy to rename between multiple mountpoints. Allowed values are SAME_MOUNTPOINT,SAME_TARGET_URI_ACROSS_MOUNTPOINT and SAME_FILESYSTEM_ACROSS_MOUNTPOINT.
label: manageability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.ftp.impl
description: The FileSystem for Ftp: uris.
label: manageability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.webhdfs.impl
description: The FileSystem for webhdfs: uris.
label: manageability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.swebhdfs.impl
description: The FileSystem for swebhdfs: uris.
label: manageability

name: fs.ftp.host
description: FTP filesystem connects to this server
label: environment

name: fs.ftp.host.port
description: FTP filesystem connects to fs.ftp.host on this port
label: environment

name: fs.ftp.data.connection.mode
description: Set the FTPClient's data connection mode based on configuration. Valid values are ACTIVE_LOCAL_DATA_CONNECTION_MODE, PASSIVE_LOCAL_DATA_CONNECTION_MODE and PASSIVE_REMOTE_DATA_CONNECTION_MODE.
label: manageability

name: fs.ftp.transfer.mode
description: Set FTP's transfer mode based on configuration. Valid values are STREAM_TRANSFER_MODE, BLOCK_TRANSFER_MODE and COMPRESSED_TRANSFER_MODE.
label: manageability

name: fs.df.interval
description: Disk usage statistics refresh interval in msec.
label: debuggability

name: fs.du.interval
description: File space usage statistics refresh interval in msec.
label: debuggability

name: fs.s3.awsAccessKeyId
description: AWS access key ID used by S3 block file system.
label: security

name: fs.s3.awsSecretAccessKey
description: AWS secret key used by S3 block file system.
label: security

name: fs.s3.block.size
description: Block size to use when writing files to S3.
label: performance

name: fs.s3.buffer.dir
description: Determines where on the local filesystem the s3:/s3n: filesystem should store files before sending them to S3 (or after retrieving them from S3).
label: environment

name: fs.s3.maxRetries
description: The maximum number of retries for reading or writing files to S3, before we signal failure to the application.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3.sleepTimeSeconds
description: The number of seconds to sleep between each S3 retry.
label: reliability

name: fs.swift.impl
description: The implementation class of the OpenStack Swift Filesystem
label: manageability

name: fs.automatic.close
description: By default, FileSystem instances are automatically closed at program exit using a JVM shutdown hook. Setting this property to false disables this behavior. This is an advanced option that should only be used by server applications requiring a more carefully orchestrated shutdown sequence.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3n.awsAccessKeyId
description: AWS access key ID used by S3 native file system.
label: security

name: fs.s3n.awsSecretAccessKey
description: AWS secret key used by S3 native file system.
label: security

name: fs.s3n.block.size
description: Block size to use when reading files using the native S3 filesystem (s3n: URIs).
label: performance

name: fs.s3n.multipart.uploads.enabled
description: Setting this property to true enables multiple uploads to native S3 filesystem. When uploading a file, it is split into blocks if the size is larger than fs.s3n.multipart.uploads.block.size.
label: performance

name: fs.s3n.multipart.uploads.block.size
description: The block size for multipart uploads to native S3 filesystem. Default size is 64MB.
label: performance

name: fs.s3n.multipart.copy.block.size
description: The block size for multipart copy in native S3 filesystem. Default size is 5GB.
label: performance

name: fs.s3n.server-side-encryption-algorithm
description: Specify a server-side encryption algorithm for S3. Unset by default, and the only other currently allowable value is AES256.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.access.key
description: AWS access key ID used by S3A file system. Omit for IAM role-based or provider-based authentication.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.secret.key
description: AWS secret key used by S3A file system. Omit for IAM role-based or provider-based authentication.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.aws.credentials.provider
description: Comma-separated class names of credential provider classes which implement com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentialsProvider. These are loaded and queried in sequence for a valid set of credentials. Each listed class must implement one of the following means of construction, which are attempted in order: 1. a public constructor accepting java.net.URI and org.apache.hadoop.conf.Configuration, 2. a public static method named getInstance that accepts no arguments and returns an instance of com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentialsProvider, or 3. a public default constructor. Specifying org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.AnonymousAWSCredentialsProvider allows anonymous access to a publicly accessible S3 bucket without any credentials. Please note that allowing anonymous access to an S3 bucket compromises security and therefore is unsuitable for most use cases. It can be useful for accessing public data sets without requiring AWS credentials. If unspecified, then the default list of credential provider classes, queried in sequence, is: 1. org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.BasicAWSCredentialsProvider: supports static configuration of AWS access key ID and secret access key. See also fs.s3a.access.key and fs.s3a.secret.key. 2. com.amazonaws.auth.EnvironmentVariableCredentialsProvider: supports configuration of AWS access key ID and secret access key in environment variables named AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID and AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, as documented in the AWS SDK. 3. org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.SharedInstanceProfileCredentialsProvider: a shared instance of com.amazonaws.auth.InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider from the AWS SDK, which supports use of instance profile credentials if running in an EC2 VM. Using this shared instance potentially reduces load on the EC2 instance metadata service for multi-threaded applications.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.session.token
description: Session token, when using org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.TemporaryAWSCredentialsProvider as one of the providers.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.security.credential.provider.path
description: Optional comma separated list of credential providers, a list which is prepended to that set in hadoop.security.credential.provider.path
label: security

name: fs.s3a.connection.maximum
description: Controls the maximum number of simultaneous connections to S3.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.connection.ssl.enabled
description: Enables or disables SSL connections to S3.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.endpoint
description: AWS S3 endpoint to connect to. An up-to-date list is provided in the AWS Documentation: regions and endpoints. Without this property, the standard region (s3.amazonaws.com) is assumed.
label: environment

name: fs.s3a.path.style.access
description: Enable S3 path style access ie disabling the default virtual hosting behaviour. Useful for S3A-compliant storage providers as it removes the need to set up DNS for virtual hosting.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.proxy.host
description: Hostname of the (optional) proxy server for S3 connections.
label: environment

name: fs.s3a.proxy.port
description: Proxy server port. If this property is not set but fs.s3a.proxy.host is, port 80 or 443 is assumed (consistent with the value of fs.s3a.connection.ssl.enabled).
label: environment

name: fs.s3a.proxy.username
description: Username for authenticating with proxy server.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.proxy.password
description: Password for authenticating with proxy server.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.proxy.domain
description: Domain for authenticating with proxy server.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.proxy.workstation
description: Workstation for authenticating with proxy server.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.attempts.maximum
description: How many times we should retry commands on transient errors.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.connection.establish.timeout
description: Socket connection setup timeout in milliseconds.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.connection.timeout
description: Socket connection timeout in milliseconds.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.socket.send.buffer
description: Socket send buffer hint to amazon connector. Represented in bytes.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.socket.recv.buffer
description: Socket receive buffer hint to amazon connector. Represented in bytes.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.paging.maximum
description: How many keys to request from S3 when doing directory listings at a time.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.threads.max
description: The total number of threads available in the filesystem for data uploads *or any other queued filesystem operation*.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.threads.keepalivetime
description: Number of seconds a thread can be idle before being terminated.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.max.total.tasks
description: The number of operations which can be queued for execution
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.multipart.size
description: How big (in bytes) to split upload or copy operations up into. A suffix from the set {K,M,G,T,P} may be used to scale the numeric value.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.multipart.threshold
description: How big (in bytes) to split upload or copy operations up into. This also controls the partition size in renamed files, as rename() involves copying the source file(s). A suffix from the set {K,M,G,T,P} may be used to scale the numeric value.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.multiobjectdelete.enable
description: When enabled, multiple single-object delete requests are replaced by a single 'delete multiple objects'-request, reducing the number of requests. Beware: legacy S3-compatible object stores might not support this request.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.acl.default
description: Set a canned ACL for newly created and copied objects. Value may be Private, PublicRead, PublicReadWrite, AuthenticatedRead, LogDeliveryWrite, BucketOwnerRead, or BucketOwnerFullControl.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.multipart.purge
description: True if you want to purge existing multipart uploads that may not have been completed/aborted correctly. The corresponding purge age is defined in fs.s3a.multipart.purge.age. If set, when the filesystem is instantiated then all outstanding uploads older than the purge age will be terminated -across the entire bucket. This will impact multipart uploads by other applications and users. so should be used sparingly, with an age value chosen to stop failed uploads, without breaking ongoing operations.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.multipart.purge.age
description: Minimum age in seconds of multipart uploads to purge.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.server-side-encryption-algorithm
description: Specify a server-side encryption algorithm for s3a: file system. Unset by default. It supports the following values: 'AES256' (for SSE-S3), 'SSE-KMS' and 'SSE-C'.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.server-side-encryption.key
description: Specific encryption key to use if fs.s3a.server-side-encryption-algorithm has been set to 'SSE-KMS' or 'SSE-C'. In the case of SSE-C, the value of this property should be the Base64 encoded key. If you are using SSE-KMS and leave this property empty, you'll be using your default's S3 KMS key, otherwise you should set this property to the specific KMS key id.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.signing-algorithm
description: Override the default signing algorithm so legacy implementations can still be used
label: security

name: fs.s3a.block.size
description: Block size to use when reading files using s3a: file system. A suffix from the set {K,M,G,T,P} may be used to scale the numeric value.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.buffer.dir
description: Comma separated list of directories that will be used to buffer file uploads to.
label: environment

name: fs.s3a.fast.upload
description: Use the incremental block-based fast upload mechanism with the buffering mechanism set in fs.s3a.fast.upload.buffer.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.fast.upload.buffer
description: The buffering mechanism to use when using S3A fast upload (fs.s3a.fast.upload=true). Values: disk, array, bytebuffer. This configuration option has no effect if fs.s3a.fast.upload is false. "disk" will use the directories listed in fs.s3a.buffer.dir as the location(s) to save data prior to being uploaded. "array" uses arrays in the JVM heap "bytebuffer" uses off-heap memory within the JVM. Both "array" and "bytebuffer" will consume memory in a single stream up to the number of blocks set by: fs.s3a.multipart.size * fs.s3a.fast.upload.active.blocks. If using either of these mechanisms, keep this value low The total number of threads performing work across all threads is set by fs.s3a.threads.max, with fs.s3a.max.total.tasks values setting the number of queued work items.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.fast.upload.active.blocks
description: Maximum Number of blocks a single output stream can have active (uploading, or queued to the central FileSystem instance's pool of queued operations. This stops a single stream overloading the shared thread pool.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.readahead.range
description: Bytes to read ahead during a seek() before closing and re-opening the S3 HTTP connection. This option will be overridden if any call to setReadahead() is made to an open stream. A suffix from the set {K,M,G,T,P} may be used to scale the numeric value.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.user.agent.prefix
description: Sets a custom value that will be prepended to the User-Agent header sent in HTTP requests to the S3 back-end by S3AFileSystem. The User-Agent header always includes the Hadoop version number followed by a string generated by the AWS SDK. An example is "User-Agent: Hadoop 2.8.0, aws-sdk-java/1.10.6". If this optional property is set, then its value is prepended to create a customized User-Agent. For example, if this configuration property was set to "MyApp", then an example of the resulting User-Agent would be "User-Agent: MyApp, Hadoop 2.8.0, aws-sdk-java/1.10.6".
label: manageability

name: fs.s3a.metadatastore.authoritative
description: When true, allow MetadataStore implementations to act as source of truth for getting file status and directory listings. Even if this is set to true, MetadataStore implementations may choose not to return authoritative results. If the configured MetadataStore does not support being authoritative, this setting will have no effect.
label: security

name: fs.s3a.metadatastore.impl
description: Fully-qualified name of the class that implements the MetadataStore to be used by s3a. The default class, NullMetadataStore, has no effect: s3a will continue to treat the backing S3 service as the one and only source of truth for file and directory metadata.
label: manageability

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.cli.prune.age
description: Default age (in milliseconds) after which to prune metadata from the metadatastore when the prune command is run. Can be overridden on the command-line.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.impl
description: The implementation class of the S3A Filesystem
label: manageability

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.region
description: AWS DynamoDB region to connect to. An up-to-date list is provided in the AWS Documentation: regions and endpoints. Without this property, the S3Guard will operate table in the associated S3 bucket region.
label: environment

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.table
description: The DynamoDB table name to operate. Without this property, the respective S3 bucket name will be used.
label: manageability

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.table.create
description: If true, the S3A client will create the table if it does not already exist.
label: manageability

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.table.capacity.read
description: Provisioned throughput requirements for read operations in terms of capacity units for the DynamoDB table. This config value will only be used when creating a new DynamoDB table, though later you can manually provision by increasing or decreasing read capacity as needed for existing tables. See DynamoDB documents for more information.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.table.capacity.write
description: Provisioned throughput requirements for write operations in terms of capacity units for the DynamoDB table. Refer to related config fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.table.capacity.read before usage.
label: performance

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.max.retries
description: Max retries on batched DynamoDB operations before giving up and throwing an IOException. Each retry is delayed with an exponential backoff timer which starts at 100 milliseconds and approximately doubles each time. The minimum wait before throwing an exception is sum(100, 200, 400, 800, .. 100*2^N-1 ) == 100 * ((2^N)-1) So N = 9 yields at least 51.1 seconds (51,100) milliseconds of blocking before throwing an IOException.
label: reliability

name: fs.s3a.s3guard.ddb.background.sleep
description: Length (in milliseconds) of pause between each batch of deletes when pruning metadata. Prevents prune operations (which can typically be low priority background operations) from overly interfering with other I/O operations.
label: reliability

name: fs.AbstractFileSystem.s3a.impl
description: The implementation class of the S3A AbstractFileSystem.
label: manageability

name: fs.wasb.impl
description: The implementation class of the Native Azure Filesystem
label: manageability

name: fs.wasbs.impl
description: The implementation class of the Secure Native Azure Filesystem
label: manageability

name: fs.azure.secure.mode
description: Config flag to identify the mode in which fs.azure.NativeAzureFileSystem needs to run under. Setting it "true" would make fs.azure.NativeAzureFileSystem use SAS keys to communicate with Azure storage.
label: security

name: fs.azure.local.sas.key.mode
description: Works in conjuction with fs.azure.secure.mode. Setting this config to true results in fs.azure.NativeAzureFileSystem using the local SAS key generation where the SAS keys are generating in the same process as fs.azure.NativeAzureFileSystem. If fs.azure.secure.mode flag is set to false, this flag has no effect.
label: security

name: fs.azure.sas.expiry.period
description: The default value to be used for expiration period for SAS keys generated. Can use the following suffix (case insensitive): ms(millis), s(sec), m(min), h(hour), d(day) to specify the time (such as 2s, 2m, 1h, etc.).
label: security

name: fs.azure.authorization
description: Config flag to enable authorization support in WASB. Setting it to "true" enables authorization support to WASB. Currently WASB authorization requires a remote service to provide authorization that needs to be specified via fs.azure.authorization.remote.service.url configuration
label: security

name: fs.azure.authorization.caching.enable
description: Config flag to enable caching of authorization results and saskeys in WASB. This flag is relevant only when fs.azure.authorization is enabled.
label: security

name: fs.azure.saskey.usecontainersaskeyforallaccess
description: Use container saskey for access to all blobs within the container. Blob-specific saskeys are not used when this setting is enabled. This setting provides better performance compared to blob-specific saskeys.
label: security

name: io.seqfile.compress.blocksize
description: The minimum block size for compression in block compressed SequenceFiles.
label: performance

name: io.mapfile.bloom.size
description: The size of BloomFilter-s used in BloomMapFile. Each time this many keys is appended the next BloomFilter will be created (inside a DynamicBloomFilter). Larger values minimize the number of filters, which slightly increases the performance, but may waste too much space if the total number of keys is usually much smaller than this number.
label: performance

name: io.mapfile.bloom.error.rate
description: The rate of false positives in BloomFilter-s used in BloomMapFile. As this value decreases, the size of BloomFilter-s increases exponentially. This value is the probability of encountering false positives (default is 0.5%).
label: performance

name: hadoop.util.hash.type
description: The default implementation of Hash. Currently this can take one of the two values: 'murmur' to select MurmurHash and 'jenkins' to select JenkinsHash.
label: manageability

name: ipc.client.idlethreshold
description: Defines the threshold number of connections after which connections will be inspected for idleness.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.kill.max
description: Defines the maximum number of clients to disconnect in one go.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.connection.maxidletime
description: The maximum time in msec after which a client will bring down the connection to the server.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.connect.max.retries
description: Indicates the number of retries a client will make to establish a server connection.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.connect.retry.interval
description: Indicates the number of milliseconds a client will wait for before retrying to establish a server connection.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.connect.timeout
description: Indicates the number of milliseconds a client will wait for the socket to establish a server connection.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.connect.max.retries.on.timeouts
description: Indicates the number of retries a client will make on socket timeout to establish a server connection.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.tcpnodelay
description: Use TCP_NODELAY flag to bypass Nagle's algorithm transmission delays.
label: performance

name: ipc.client.low-latency
description: Use low-latency QoS markers for IPC connections.
label: performance

name: ipc.client.ping
description: Send a ping to the server when timeout on reading the response, if set to true. If no failure is detected, the client retries until at least a byte is read or the time given by ipc.client.rpc-timeout.ms is passed.
label: reliability

name: ipc.ping.interval
description: Timeout on waiting response from server, in milliseconds. The client will send ping when the interval is passed without receiving bytes, if ipc.client.ping is set to true.
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.rpc-timeout.ms
description: Timeout on waiting response from server, in milliseconds. If ipc.client.ping is set to true and this rpc-timeout is greater than the value of ipc.ping.interval, the effective value of the rpc-timeout is rounded up to multiple of ipc.ping.interval.
label: reliability

name: ipc.server.listen.queue.size
description: Indicates the length of the listen queue for servers accepting client connections.
label: performance

name: ipc.server.log.slow.rpc
description: This setting is useful to troubleshoot performance issues for various services. If this value is set to true then we log requests that fall into 99th percentile as well as increment RpcSlowCalls counter.
label: debuggability

name: ipc.maximum.data.length
description: This indicates the maximum IPC message length (bytes) that can be accepted by the server. Messages larger than this value are rejected by the immediately to avoid possible OOMs. This setting should rarely need to be changed.
label: reliability

name: ipc.maximum.response.length
description: This indicates the maximum IPC message length (bytes) that can be accepted by the client. Messages larger than this value are rejected immediately to avoid possible OOMs. This setting should rarely need to be changed. Set to 0 to disable.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.impersonation.provider.class
description: A class which implements ImpersonationProvider interface, used to authorize whether one user can impersonate a specific user. If not specified, the DefaultImpersonationProvider will be used. If a class is specified, then that class will be used to determine the impersonation capability.
label: security

name: hadoop.rpc.socket.factory.class.default
description: Default SocketFactory to use. This parameter is expected to be formatted as "package.FactoryClassName".
label: environment

name: hadoop.rpc.socket.factory.class.ClientProtocol
description: SocketFactory to use to connect to a DFS. If null or empty, use hadoop.rpc.socket.class.default. This socket factory is also used by DFSClient to create sockets to DataNodes.
label: environment

name: hadoop.socks.server
description: Address (host:port) of the SOCKS server to be used by the SocksSocketFactory.
label: environment

name: net.topology.node.switch.mapping.impl
description: The default implementation of the DNSToSwitchMapping. It invokes a script specified in net.topology.script.file.name to resolve node names. If the value for net.topology.script.file.name is not set, the default value of DEFAULT_RACK is returned for all node names.
label: manageability

name: net.topology.impl
description: The default implementation of NetworkTopology which is classic three layer one.
label: manageability

name: net.topology.script.file.name
description: The script name that should be invoked to resolve DNS names to NetworkTopology names. Example: the script would take host.foo.bar as an argument, and return /rack1 as the output.
label: environment

name: net.topology.script.number.args
description: The max number of args that the script configured with net.topology.script.file.name should be run with. Each arg is an IP address.
label: manageability

name: net.topology.table.file.name
description: The file name for a topology file, which is used when the net.topology.node.switch.mapping.impl property is set to org.apache.hadoop.net.TableMapping. The file format is a two column text file, with columns separated by whitespace. The first column is a DNS or IP address and the second column specifies the rack where the address maps. If no entry corresponding to a host in the cluster is found, then /default-rack is assumed.
label: environment

name: file.stream-buffer-size
description: The size of buffer to stream files. The size of this buffer should probably be a multiple of hardware page size (4096 on Intel x86), and it determines how much data is buffered during read and write operations.
label: performance

name: file.bytes-per-checksum
description: The number of bytes per checksum. Must not be larger than file.stream-buffer-size
label: performance

name: file.client-write-packet-size
description: Packet size for clients to write
label: performance

name: file.blocksize
description: Block size
label: performance

name: file.replication
description: Replication factor
label: reliability

name: s3.stream-buffer-size
description: The size of buffer to stream files. The size of this buffer should probably be a multiple of hardware page size (4096 on Intel x86), and it determines how much data is buffered during read and write operations.
label: performance

name: s3.bytes-per-checksum
description: The number of bytes per checksum. Must not be larger than s3.stream-buffer-size
label: performance

name: s3.client-write-packet-size
description: Packet size for clients to write
label: performance

name: s3.blocksize
description: Block size
label: performance

name: s3.replication
description: Replication factor
label: reliability

name: s3native.stream-buffer-size
description: The size of buffer to stream files. The size of this buffer should probably be a multiple of hardware page size (4096 on Intel x86), and it determines how much data is buffered during read and write operations.
label: performance

name: s3native.bytes-per-checksum
description: The number of bytes per checksum. Must not be larger than s3native.stream-buffer-size
label: performance

name: s3native.client-write-packet-size
description: Packet size for clients to write
label: performance

name: s3native.blocksize
description: Block size
label: performance

name: s3native.replication
description: Replication factor
label: reliability

name: ftp.stream-buffer-size
description: The size of buffer to stream files. The size of this buffer should probably be a multiple of hardware page size (4096 on Intel x86), and it determines how much data is buffered during read and write operations.
label: performance

name: ftp.bytes-per-checksum
description: The number of bytes per checksum. Must not be larger than ftp.stream-buffer-size
label: performance

name: ftp.client-write-packet-size
description: Packet size for clients to write
label: performance

name: ftp.blocksize
description: Block size
label: performance

name: ftp.replication
description: Replication factor
label: reliability

name: tfile.io.chunk.size
description: Value chunk size in bytes. Default to 1MB. Values of the length less than the chunk size is guaranteed to have known value length in read time (See also TFile.Reader.Scanner.Entry.isValueLengthKnown()).
label: performance

name: tfile.fs.output.buffer.size
description: Buffer size used for FSDataOutputStream in bytes.
label: performance

name: tfile.fs.input.buffer.size
description: Buffer size used for FSDataInputStream in bytes.
label: performance

name: hadoop.http.authentication.type
description: Defines authentication used for Oozie HTTP endpoint. Supported values are: simple | kerberos | #AUTHENTICATION_HANDLER_CLASSNAME#
label: security

name: hadoop.http.authentication.token.validity
description: Indicates how long (in seconds) an authentication token is valid before it has to be renewed.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.authentication.signature.secret.file
description: The signature secret for signing the authentication tokens. The same secret should be used for JT/NN/DN/TT configurations.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.authentication.cookie.domain
description: The domain to use for the HTTP cookie that stores the authentication token. In order to authentiation to work correctly across all Hadoop nodes web-consoles the domain must be correctly set. IMPORTANT: when using IP addresses, browsers ignore cookies with domain settings. For this setting to work properly all nodes in the cluster must be configured to generate URLs with hostname.domain names on it.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.authentication.simple.anonymous.allowed
description: Indicates if anonymous requests are allowed when using 'simple' authentication.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.authentication.kerberos.principal
description: Indicates the Kerberos principal to be used for HTTP endpoint. The principal MUST start with 'HTTP/' as per Kerberos HTTP SPNEGO specification.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.authentication.kerberos.keytab
description: Location of the keytab file with the credentials for the principal. Referring to the same keytab file Oozie uses for its Kerberos credentials for Hadoop.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.cross-origin.enabled
description: Enable/disable the cross-origin (CORS) filter.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.http.cross-origin.allowed-origins
description: Comma separated list of origins that are allowed for web services needing cross-origin (CORS) support. Wildcards (*) and patterns allowed
label: manageability

name: hadoop.http.cross-origin.allowed-methods
description: Comma separated list of methods that are allowed for web services needing cross-origin (CORS) support.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.http.cross-origin.allowed-headers
description: Comma separated list of headers that are allowed for web services needing cross-origin (CORS) support.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.http.cross-origin.max-age
description: The number of seconds a pre-flighted request can be cached for web services needing cross-origin (CORS) support.
label: reliability

name: dfs.ha.fencing.methods
description: List of fencing methods to use for service fencing. May contain builtin methods (eg shell and sshfence) or user-defined method.
label: reliability

name: dfs.ha.fencing.ssh.connect-timeout
description: SSH connection timeout, in milliseconds, to use with the builtin sshfence fencer.
label: reliability

name: dfs.ha.fencing.ssh.private-key-files
description: The SSH private key files to use with the builtin sshfence fencer.
label: security

name: hadoop.http.staticuser.user
description: The user name to filter as, on static web filters while rendering content. An example use is the HDFS web UI (user to be used for browsing files).
label: manageability

name: ha.zookeeper.quorum
description: A list of ZooKeeper server addresses, separated by commas, that are to be used by the ZKFailoverController in automatic failover.
label: environment

name: ha.zookeeper.session-timeout.ms
description: The session timeout to use when the ZKFC connects to ZooKeeper. Setting this value to a lower value implies that server crashes will be detected more quickly, but risks triggering failover too aggressively in the case of a transient error or network blip.
label: reliability

name: ha.zookeeper.parent-znode
description: The ZooKeeper znode under which the ZK failover controller stores its information. Note that the nameservice ID is automatically appended to this znode, so it is not normally necessary to configure this, even in a federated environment.
label: reliability

name: ha.zookeeper.acl
description: A comma-separated list of ZooKeeper ACLs to apply to the znodes used by automatic failover. These ACLs are specified in the same format as used by the ZooKeeper CLI. If the ACL itself contains secrets, you may instead specify a path to a file, prefixed with the '@' symbol, and the value of this configuration will be loaded from within.
label: security

name: ha.zookeeper.auth
description: A comma-separated list of ZooKeeper authentications to add when connecting to ZooKeeper. These are specified in the same format as used by the "addauth" command in the ZK CLI. It is important that the authentications specified here are sufficient to access znodes with the ACL specified in ha.zookeeper.acl. If the auths contain secrets, you may instead specify a path to a file, prefixed with the '@' symbol, and the value of this configuration will be loaded from within.
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.keystores.factory.class
description: The keystores factory to use for retrieving certificates.
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.require.client.cert
description: Whether client certificates are required
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.hostname.verifier
description: The hostname verifier to provide for HttpsURLConnections. Valid values are: DEFAULT, STRICT, STRICT_IE6, DEFAULT_AND_LOCALHOST and ALLOW_ALL
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.server.conf
description: Resource file from which ssl server keystore information will be extracted. This file is looked up in the classpath, typically it should be in Hadoop conf/ directory.
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.client.conf
description: Resource file from which ssl client keystore information will be extracted This file is looked up in the classpath, typically it should be in Hadoop conf/ directory.
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.enabled
description: Deprecated. Use dfs.http.policy and yarn.http.policy instead.
label: security

name: hadoop.ssl.enabled.protocols
description: The supported SSL protocols.
label: security

name: hadoop.jetty.logs.serve.aliases
description: Enable/Disable aliases serving from jetty
label: manageability

name: fs.permissions.umask-mode
description: The umask used when creating files and directories. Can be in octal or in symbolic. Examples are: "022" (octal for u=rwx,g=r-x,o=r-x in symbolic), or "u=rwx,g=rwx,o=" (symbolic for 007 in octal).
label: security

name: ha.health-monitor.connect-retry-interval.ms
description: How often to retry connecting to the service.
label: reliability

name: ha.health-monitor.check-interval.ms
description: How often to check the service.
label: reliability

name: ha.health-monitor.sleep-after-disconnect.ms
description: How long to sleep after an unexpected RPC error.
label: reliability

name: ha.health-monitor.rpc-timeout.ms
description: Timeout for the actual monitorHealth() calls.
label: reliability

name: ha.failover-controller.new-active.rpc-timeout.ms
description: Timeout that the FC waits for the new active to become active
label: reliability

name: ha.failover-controller.graceful-fence.rpc-timeout.ms
description: Timeout that the FC waits for the old active to go to standby
label: reliability

name: ha.failover-controller.graceful-fence.connection.retries
description: FC connection retries for graceful fencing
label: reliability

name: ha.failover-controller.cli-check.rpc-timeout.ms
description: Timeout that the CLI (manual) FC waits for monitorHealth, getServiceState
label: reliability

name: ipc.client.fallback-to-simple-auth-allowed
description: When a client is configured to attempt a secure connection, but attempts to connect to an insecure server, that server may instruct the client to switch to SASL SIMPLE (unsecure) authentication. This setting controls whether or not the client will accept this instruction from the server. When false (the default), the client will not allow the fallback to SIMPLE authentication, and will abort the connection.
label: security

name: fs.client.resolve.remote.symlinks
description: Whether to resolve symlinks when accessing a remote Hadoop filesystem. Setting this to false causes an exception to be thrown upon encountering a symlink. This setting does not apply to local filesystems, which automatically resolve local symlinks.
label: reliability

name: nfs.exports.allowed.hosts
description: By default, the export can be mounted by any client. The value string contains machine name and access privilege, separated by whitespace characters. The machine name format can be a single host, a Java regular expression, or an IPv4 address. The access privilege uses rw or ro to specify read/write or read-only access of the machines to exports. If the access privilege is not provided, the default is read-only. Entries are separated by ";". For example: "192.168.0.0/22 rw ; host.*\.example\.com ; host1.test.org ro;". Only the NFS gateway needs to restart after this property is updated.
label: security

name: hadoop.user.group.static.mapping.overrides
description: Static mapping of user to groups. This will override the groups if available in the system for the specified user. In other words, groups look-up will not happen for these users, instead groups mapped in this configuration will be used. Mapping should be in this format. user1=group1,group2;user2=;user3=group2; Default, "dr.who=;" will consider "dr.who" as user without groups.
label: security

name: rpc.metrics.quantile.enable
description: Setting this property to true and rpc.metrics.percentiles.intervals to a comma-separated list of the granularity in seconds, the 50/75/90/95/99th percentile latency for rpc queue/processing time in milliseconds are added to rpc metrics.
label: reliability

name: rpc.metrics.percentiles.intervals
description: A comma-separated list of the granularity in seconds for the metrics which describe the 50/75/90/95/99th percentile latency for rpc queue/processing time. The metrics are outputted if rpc.metrics.quantile.enable is set to true.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.crypto.codec.classes.EXAMPLECIPHERSUITE
description: The prefix for a given crypto codec, contains a comma-separated list of implementation classes for a given crypto codec (eg EXAMPLECIPHERSUITE). The first implementation will be used if available, others are fallbacks.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.crypto.codec.classes.aes.ctr.nopadding
description: Comma-separated list of crypto codec implementations for AES/CTR/NoPadding. The first implementation will be used if available, others are fallbacks.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.crypto.cipher.suite
description: Cipher suite for crypto codec.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.crypto.jce.provider
description: The JCE provider name used in CryptoCodec.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.crypto.jceks.key.serialfilter
description: Enhanced KeyStore Mechanisms in JDK 8u171 introduced jceks.key.serialFilter. If jceks.key.serialFilter is configured, the JCEKS KeyStore uses it during the deserialization of the encrypted Key object stored inside a SecretKeyEntry. If jceks.key.serialFilter is not configured it will cause an error when recovering keystore file in KeyProviderFactory when recovering key from keystore file using JDK 8u171 or newer. The filter pattern uses the same format as jdk.serialFilter. The value of this property will be used as the following: 1. The value of jceks.key.serialFilter system property takes precedence over the value of this property. 2. In the absence of jceks.key.serialFilter system property the value of this property will be set as the value of jceks.key.serialFilter. 3. If the value of this property and jceks.key.serialFilter system property has not been set, org.apache.hadoop.crypto.key.KeyProvider sets a default value for jceks.key.serialFilter.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.crypto.buffer.size
description: The buffer size used by CryptoInputStream and CryptoOutputStream.
label: performance

name: hadoop.security.java.secure.random.algorithm
description: The java secure random algorithm.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.secure.random.impl
description: Implementation of secure random.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.random.device.file.path
description: OS security random device file path.
label: security

name: hadoop.security.key.provider.path
description: The KeyProvider to use when managing zone keys, and interacting with encryption keys when reading and writing to an encryption zone. For hdfs clients, the provider path will be same as namenode's provider path.
label: security

name: fs.har.impl.disable.cache
description: Don't cache 'har' filesystem instances.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.authentication.retry-count
description: Number of time to retry connecting to KMS on authentication failure
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.encrypted.key.cache.size
description: Size of the EncryptedKeyVersion cache Queue for each key
label: performance

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.encrypted.key.cache.low-watermark
description: If size of the EncryptedKeyVersion cache Queue falls below the low watermark, this cache queue will be scheduled for a refill
label: performance

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.encrypted.key.cache.num.refill.threads
description: Number of threads to use for refilling depleted EncryptedKeyVersion cache Queues
label: performance

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.encrypted.key.cache.expiry
description: Cache expiry time for a Key, after which the cache Queue for this key will be dropped. Default = 12hrs
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.timeout
description: Sets value for KMS client connection timeout, and the read timeout to KMS servers.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.failover.sleep.base.millis
description: Expert only. The time to wait, in milliseconds, between failover attempts increases exponentially as a function of the number of attempts made so far, with a random factor of +/- 50%. This option specifies the base value used in the failover calculation. The first failover will retry immediately. The 2nd failover attempt will delay at least hadoop.security.client.failover.sleep.base.millis milliseconds. And so on.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.security.kms.client.failover.sleep.max.millis
description: Expert only. The time to wait, in milliseconds, between failover attempts increases exponentially as a function of the number of attempts made so far, with a random factor of +/- 50%. This option specifies the maximum value to wait between failovers. Specifically, the time between two failover attempts will not exceed +/- 50% of hadoop.security.client.failover.sleep.max.millis milliseconds.
label: reliability

name: ipc.server.max.connections
description: The maximum number of concurrent connections a server is allowed to accept. If this limit is exceeded, incoming connections will first fill the listen queue and then may go to an OS-specific listen overflow queue. The client may fail or timeout, but the server can avoid running out of file descriptors using this feature. 0 means no limit.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.registry.rm.enabled
description: Is the registry enabled in the YARN Resource Manager? If true, the YARN RM will, as needed. create the user and system paths, and purge service records when containers, application attempts and applications complete. If false, the paths must be created by other means, and no automatic cleanup of service records will take place.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.registry.zk.root
description: The root zookeeper node for the registry
label: environment

name: hadoop.registry.zk.session.timeout.ms
description: Zookeeper session timeout in milliseconds
label: reliability

name: hadoop.registry.zk.connection.timeout.ms
description: Zookeeper connection timeout in milliseconds
label: reliability

name: hadoop.registry.zk.retry.times
description: Zookeeper connection retry count before failing
label: reliability

name: hadoop.registry.zk.retry.ceiling.ms
description: Zookeeper retry limit in milliseconds, during exponential backoff. This places a limit even if the retry times and interval limit, combined with the backoff policy, result in a long retry period
label: reliability

name: hadoop.registry.zk.quorum
description: List of hostname:port pairs defining the zookeeper quorum binding for the registry
label: environment

name: hadoop.registry.secure
description: Key to set if the registry is secure. Turning it on changes the permissions policy from "open access" to restrictions on kerberos with the option of a user adding one or more auth key pairs down their own tree.
label: security

name: hadoop.registry.system.acls
description: A comma separated list of Zookeeper ACL identifiers with system access to the registry in a secure cluster. These are given full access to all entries. If there is an "@" at the end of a SASL entry it instructs the registry client to append the default kerberos domain.
label: security

name: hadoop.registry.kerberos.realm
description: The kerberos realm: used to set the realm of system principals which do not declare their realm, and any other accounts that need the value. If empty, the default realm of the running process is used. If neither are known and the realm is needed, then the registry service/client will fail.
label: security

name: hadoop.registry.jaas.context
description: Key to define the JAAS context. Used in secure mode
label: security

name: hadoop.shell.missing.defaultFs.warning
description: Enable hdfs shell commands to display warnings if (fs.defaultFS) property is not set.
label: debuggability

name: hadoop.shell.safely.delete.limit.num.files
description: Used by -safely option of hadoop fs shell -rm command to avoid accidental deletion of large directories. When enabled, the -rm command requires confirmation if the number of files to be deleted is greater than this limit. The default limit is 100 files. The warning is disabled if the limit is 0 or the -safely is not specified in -rm command.
label: security

name: fs.client.htrace.sampler.classes
description: The class names of the HTrace Samplers to use for Hadoop filesystem clients.
label: debuggability

name: hadoop.htrace.span.receiver.classes
description: The class names of the Span Receivers to use for Hadoop.
label: manageability

name: hadoop.http.logs.enabled
description: Enable the "/logs" endpoint on all Hadoop daemons, which serves local logs, but may be considered a security risk due to it listing the contents of a directory.
label: debuggability

name: fs.client.resolve.topology.enabled
description: Whether the client machine will use the class specified by property net.topology.node.switch.mapping.impl to compute the network distance between itself and remote machines of the FileSystem. Additional properties might need to be configured depending on the class specified in net.topology.node.switch.mapping.impl. For example, if org.apache.hadoop.net.ScriptBasedMapping is used, a valid script file needs to be specified in net.topology.script.file.name.
label: manageability

name: adl.feature.ownerandgroup.enableupn
description: When true : User and Group in FileStatus/AclStatus response is represented as user friendly name as per Azure AD profile. When false (default) : User and Group in FileStatus/AclStatus response is represented by the unique identifier from Azure AD profile (Object ID as GUID). For optimal performance, false is recommended.
label: performance

name: fs.adl.oauth2.access.token.provider.type
description: Defines Azure Active Directory OAuth2 access token provider type. Supported types are ClientCredential, RefreshToken, MSI, DeviceCode, and Custom. The ClientCredential type requires property fs.adl.oauth2.client.id, fs.adl.oauth2.credential, and fs.adl.oauth2.refresh.url. The RefreshToken type requires property fs.adl.oauth2.client.id and fs.adl.oauth2.refresh.token. The MSI type reads optional property fs.adl.oauth2.msi.port, if specified. The DeviceCode type requires property fs.adl.oauth2.devicecode.clientapp.id. The Custom type requires property fs.adl.oauth2.access.token.provider.
label: security

name: fs.adl.oauth2.client.id
description: The OAuth2 client id.
label: security

name: fs.adl.oauth2.credential
description: The OAuth2 access key.
label: security

name: fs.adl.oauth2.refresh.url
description: The OAuth2 token endpoint.
label: security

name: fs.adl.oauth2.refresh.token
description: The OAuth2 refresh token.
label: security

name: fs.adl.oauth2.access.token.provider
description: The class name of the OAuth2 access token provider.
label: security

name: fs.adl.oauth2.msi.port
description: The localhost port for the MSI token service. This is the port specified when creating the Azure VM. The default, if this setting is not specified, is 50342. Used by MSI token provider.
label: environment

name: fs.adl.oauth2.devicecode.clientapp.id
description: The app id of the AAD native app in whose context the auth request should be made. Used by DeviceCode token provider.
label: environment

name: hadoop.caller.context.enabled
description: When the feature is enabled, additional fields are written into name-node audit log records for auditing coarse granularity operations.
label: debuggability

name: hadoop.caller.context.max.size
description: The maximum bytes a caller context string can have. If the passed caller context is longer than this maximum bytes, client will truncate it before sending to server. Note that the server may have a different maximum size, and will truncate the caller context to the maximum size it allows.
label: performance

name: hadoop.caller.context.signature.max.size
description: The caller's signature (optional) is for offline validation. If the signature exceeds the maximum allowed bytes in server, the caller context will be abandoned, in which case the caller context will not be recorded in audit logs.
label: security

name: seq.io.sort.mb
description: The total amount of buffer memory to use while sorting files, while using SequenceFile.Sorter, in megabytes. By default, gives each merge stream 1MB, which should minimize seeks.
label: performance

name: seq.io.sort.factor
description: The number of streams to merge at once while sorting files using SequenceFile.Sorter. This determines the number of open file handles.
label: performance

name: hadoop.zk.address
description: Host:Port of the ZooKeeper server to be used.
label: environment

name: hadoop.zk.num-retries
description: Number of tries to connect to ZooKeeper.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.zk.retry-interval-ms
description: Retry interval in milliseconds when connecting to ZooKeeper.
label: reliability

name: hadoop.zk.timeout-ms
description: ZooKeeper session timeout in milliseconds. Session expiration is managed by the ZooKeeper cluster itself, not by the client. This value is used by the cluster to determine when the client's session expires. Expirations happens when the cluster does not hear from the client within the specified session timeout period (i.e. no heartbeat).
label: reliability

name: hadoop.zk.acl
description: ACL's to be used for ZooKeeper znodes.
label: security

name: hadoop.zk.auth
description: Specify the auths to be used for the ACL's specified in hadoop.zk.acl. This takes a comma-separated list of authentication mechanisms, each of the form 'scheme:auth' (the same syntax used for the 'addAuth' command in the ZK CLI).
label: security
